output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of microprocessors, their architecture, and their applications. By completing this course, you will be equipped with the knowledge and skills necessary to design, develop, and troubleshoot microprocessor-based systems.
output.introduction: Welcome to the Microprocessors course! This course is designed for intermediate-level learners who have a basic understanding of digital logic and computer architecture. We will delve into the core concepts of microprocessors, exploring their architecture, instruction sets, and programming techniques.

chapters.description: Overview of microprocessors, their evolution, and applications. Key components of a microprocessor: ALU, control unit, registers. Different types of microprocessors: CISC vs. RISC.
Detailed explanation of microprocessor architecture. Instruction execution cycle. Memory organization and addressing modes. Input/Output (I/O) techniques.
Introduction to instruction set architecture. Instruction formats and types. Addressing modes: immediate, direct, indirect, register, etc.
Introduction to assembly language. Assembly language syntax and structure. Basic assembly language instructions: data transfer, arithmetic, logical, control flow.
Memory organization and types: RAM, ROM, EPROM, EEPROM. Memory address decoding techniques. Interfacing memory with microprocessors.
I/O interfacing techniques: memory-mapped I/O, I/O-mapped I/O. Parallel and serial communication interfaces. Interrupt handling.
Interrupts: types, sources, and handling. Interrupt service routines (ISRs). Exception handling mechanisms.
DMA concepts and operation. DMA controllers. Advantages and disadvantages of DMA.
Microprocessors in embedded systems. Microprocessors in personal computers. Microprocessors in industrial control systems.
Introduction to pipelining, caching, and multi-core processors. Overview of modern microprocessor architectures.
